findings: MEDIUM: LO#1 mentions 'four-layer payment stack' before it is introduced (frame 2).
MEDIUM: LO#4 uses 'interchange' -- term not defined until frame 7. Students see it cold here.
LOW: LO#2 mentions 'settlement' before the prerequisite frame defines it on the next slide.
HIGH: 'Clearing' is listed as essential component #2 but never revisited or explained beyond 'verification and reconciliation'. For BSc students with no finance background this is a gap.
LOW: 'Float' is defined in Key Terms, good practice.
LOW: Dual definition of 'settlement' (item #3 and Key Terms box) is slightly redundant but reinforcing.

frame_title: The Hidden Journey of a Payment
findings: LOW: TikZ diagram uses custom styles (process, arrow) from template -- should compile cleanly.
LOW: The (cont.) frame is very thin (insight block only). Could be combined with main frame to reduce slide count.
LOW: 'banking consortia' used without definition (line 119). Minor -- context makes it clear.
LOW: Good reinforcement of authorization vs settlement distinction.
LOW: 'Issuing bank' and 'acquiring bank' are footnoted (lines 171-172). Good practice for BSc audience.
LOW: Network effects diagram is clear and self-contained.

prerequisite_knowledge: card networks (frame 5), API concept is helpful but not required
findings: MEDIUM: 'APIs' mentioned (line 210) but not defined until T2.2. BSc students may not know the term.
LOW: Before/after comparison is effective pedagogically.
LOW: 'cross-selling' (line 265) used without definition. Context makes it inferable but BSc students may not know the term.
LOW: 'Think About It' block is good engagement.

prerequisite_knowledge: issuing bank, acquiring bank (frame 5), authorization vs settlement (frame 4)
findings: MEDIUM: Dense TikZ diagram with 6 numbered steps and 5 nodes. Cognitive load is high for students encountering this for the first time.

LOW: Arrow step 5 goes from issuer to cardholder which is an unusual representation -- the approval flows back through the network and acquirer. Simplification is acceptable for BSc level but slightly misleading.
MEDIUM: 'assessment fees' (line 342) used without definition. BSc students will not know this term.
LOW: Good insight about consumer ultimately paying through prices.
LOW: 'Interchange fees' properly introduced and explained. 'Cross-subsidization' footnoted. Good.
LOW: Think About It question on (cont.) slide is effective.

MEDIUM: 'Chargebacks' mentioned in parenthetical (line 417) before being defined in frame 13 (line 593). Used before defined.
LOW: Table format is effective for comparison.

LOW: Good comparison to card networks on the (cont.) slide.
LOW: 'Micropayments' mentioned (line 475) without definition, but inferable from context.
LOW: 'Correspondent banking' is properly footnoted (line 518). Good practice.
LOW: TikZ diagram with fee hops is clear and intuitive.
LOW: 'Anti-money laundering' (line 515) is used as a descriptor but not formally defined. Inferable.

MEDIUM: 'Blockchain Settlement' (column 2) references blockchain before Day 3 coverage. Forward dependency.
LOW: Three-column layout for three approaches is effective.
LOW: 'Chargeback' properly footnoted (line 594). Good.
LOW: 'False positive' is explained inline. Good practice for BSc level.
LOW: Think About It on (cont.) slide is effective engagement.
LOW: 'Underwriting' is properly footnoted on the (cont.) slide (line 673). Good.
LOW: Business model tensions are clearly laid out.
LOW: (cont.) slide has both alertblock and insight -- slightly dense but manageable.
LOW: 'Network graph' (line 706) may be unfamiliar but is introduced in the exercise context.
LOW: 'No Programming Prerequisites' box is reassuring for the target audience. Good.
LOW: Four-part structure is clear. Good scaffolding.
LOW: 'Summary statistics' and 'network analysis' may be new concepts for some BSc students but are standard.

LOW: 'No single right answers' disclaimer is appropriate.
LOW: Good synthesis slide. Discussion questions reference earlier concepts.
LOW: 'Why haven't cryptocurrencies replaced traditional payments' previews Day 3 material but as a question, not an assertion.
LOW: Five takeaways are concise and well-structured.
LOW: One-sentence summary is effective.
LOW: Concept map is a good visual summary. Reading instruction provided.
LOW: Seven terms defined. All were introduced earlier in the slides. Good consolidation.
LOW: Four myth/reality pairs are well-chosen and address likely student misunderstandings.
LOW: Three questions map to LOs well. Mastery check is appropriate.

frame_title: What's Next: Topic 2.2 --- The API Economy
findings: MEDIUM: 'Embedded finance' (line 979) is mentioned in the preview without definition. Not critical since it is a preview, but students may wonder.

frame_title: AISP and PISP: Read Access vs. Write Access
findings: HIGH: AISP and PISP are two new acronyms introduced simultaneously. For BSc students, two new abbreviations plus their full names is a lot to absorb in one frame.
MEDIUM: 'TPP (Third Party Provider)' and 'account aggregation' are introduced in the jargon box on the (cont.) slide. Good, but adds to total concept count (4 new terms on this logical slide).
LOW: Read vs write framing is intuitive.

frame_title: Open Banking Architecture: The Consent Flow
findings: MEDIUM: 'Access token' (line 459) and 'API gateway' (line 454) are used in the TikZ diagram without prior definition. The (cont.) slide explains tokens via analogy (concert wristband), but the main frame uses the term first.
LOW: TikZ consent flow is clear with numbered steps.
HIGH: Six API types introduced in a single table. This is 6 new concepts in one frame -- exceeds the 5-concept threshold.
LOW: 'KYC' is explained in the jargon box (line 507). Good.
LOW: Table format is readable.

LOW: Without/With BaaS comparison is effective.

frame_title: BaaS Business Model: How Everyone Gets Paid
findings: MEDIUM: 'Interest spread' (line 609) -- the concept of the difference between deposit and lending rates is not explained for BSc students. Quick parenthetical helps but the term itself is jargon.
LOW: Interchange is re-explained in the jargon box (line 632). Good cross-reference to T2.1.
LOW: 'Who Gets What' framing is clear.

findings: LOW: Conceptual examples are concrete and relatable (e-commerce, ride-sharing, retail, freelancing).

LOW: Valet key analogy is excellent for BSc audience.
LOW: Old way vs new way comparison is effective.
MEDIUM: 'Concentration risk' (line 737) -- financial jargon not defined. BSc students may not know this term.

LOW: 'Anti-money-laundering' (line 746) is used again without formal definition but is descriptive.

frame_title: Discussion: Who Wins in Open Banking?
findings: LOW: Winners/Losers/Uncertain three-column is effective.

frame_title: Concept Map: The API Economy Ecosystem

LOW: Good bridge linking Open Banking APIs to data-driven finance.
LOW: Preview of T2.3 is clear.

frame_title: What Matters Most in a Credit Score
findings: LOW: TikZ bar chart showing relative importance without exact percentages is a good choice for BSc level.

LOW: TikZ pipeline diagram is clear.

frame_title: Feature Engineering: From Raw Data to Useful Signals
findings: MEDIUM: Frame is [fragile] with lstlisting code. While the code is commented pseudo-code, BSc students with no programming background may find it somewhat intimidating despite the 'no prerequisites' promise.
LOW: 'Feature engineering' is properly explained here. Good follow-up to frame 12.
LOW: Exam analogy for overfitting is excellent. BSc students will relate immediately.
LOW: Training/testing split is well-explained without formulas.

HIGH: Three fairness concepts (demographic parity, equalized odds, calibration) are introduced in a single bullet list (lines 691-694) without examples. BSc students will struggle with these technical definitions.
MEDIUM: Four sources of bias + three fairness concepts + real-world example = very dense frame. Consider splitting.
LOW: Apple Card example is redacted to 'major technology company' -- good practice for no-company-names policy.
HIGH: Multiple advanced concepts in one logical slide: disparate impact, proxy variables, redlining, adversarial debiasing. This exceeds 5 new concepts.
MEDIUM: 'Adversarial debiasing' (line 762) is mentioned without explanation. Technical ML jargon inappropriate for BSc audience.
LOW: 'Redlining' historical context box is good. Adds necessary background.
LOW: The (cont.) slide with testing methods is a natural extension.

frame_title: Explainability: The Right to Know Why
findings: HIGH: Three explainability techniques (feature importance, SHAP values, partial dependence) introduced. SHAP is explained via restaurant bill analogy, which helps, but 'partial dependence' gets no analogy.
MEDIUM: 'Adverse action notice' is properly explained. Good.
LOW: SHAP restaurant bill analogy is effective.

frame_title: Beyond Credit: Algorithms Everywhere in Finance
findings: HIGH: Four application domains (insurance, investment, fraud, KYC) with 4 items each = 16 bullet points across two frames. Very dense.

LOW: 'Robo-advisors' (line 832) are mentioned here and will be covered in Day 6. Forward reference.
MEDIUM: 'Moat' (line 934) is business jargon used without definition. Will be explained in T2.4 but appears here first.
LOW: Flywheel TikZ diagram is clear and self-explanatory.
LOW: (cont.) slide comparison of incumbents vs newcomers is well-balanced.

findings: LOW: Six-step exercise is well-scaffolded and maps to the pipeline.
